node.title: Shark attacks could be a case of mistaken identity
node.description: International and Australian scientists are challenging the common notion that great whites are "mindless killers"Â or "fond of human flesh".
node.content:
["International and Australian scientists have tested the long-held theory that some shark attacks could be the result of mistaken identity, challenging the common notion that great whites are \"mindless killers\"\u00a0or \"fond of human flesh.\"", "Researchers have studied the anatomy of shark eyes to gain a perspective on\u00a0what they might see underwater while they look up to the ocean's surface for prey.", "Lead researcher from Macquarie University Dr Laura Ryan said it is the first study of its kind.", "\"Until now, the potential similarity between humans and seals has been assessed based on human vision,\" she said.\u00a0", "\"However, white sharks have much lower visual acuity than us, meaning they cannot see fine details, and lack colour vision.\"\u00a0", "
Mistaken silhouettes\u00a0
", "", "
Charlie Huveneers said some electric deterrent\u00a0devices had been shown to\u00a0reduce\u00a0the risk of shark bites by about 60 per cent.(Supplied: Flinders University)
", "Flinders University associate professor Charlie Huveneers said the studies are indicating sharks are likely mistaking the silhouettes of surfers for\u00a0their natural prey like seals.", "\"Humans have three different types of cones to process colour, while sharks only have one type of cone \u2014 which means they're unlikely to see colour,\" Mr Huveneers said.", "\"While they're well adapted to see underwater, their acuity is not as good as previously thought and the ability to discern the resolution of images isn't that great.", "", "
Researchers believe sharks could be mistaking surfers for seals as they look up to the surface due to poor acuity and lack of colour vision.(Supplied: Jeremy Ievins)
", "
Why sharks bite
", "Mr Huveneers said the study could\u00a0contribute to reducing the risk\u00a0of shark bites.", "\"There's been some questions about what could be the reason behind why sharks might be biting humans and a better understanding might help us mitigate these risks.\"", "The researcher said a combination of devices that deter sharks and knowledge from this recent study could help reduce the risk of shark bites.", "\"There's no silver bullet, or one device or product which will completely reduce the risk;\u00a0it's a combination of these devices that together can reduce the risk,\" he said.", "The researchers acknowledged sharks can also detect prey using other sensory systems.", "\"What we're showing from a vision perspective and an anatomical perspective is\u00a0there seem\u00a0to be sharks that are not the best at differentiating different objects on the surface,\" Mr Huveneers said.", "Dr Ryan noted\u00a0\"the findings of this study have inspired the design of non-invasive vision-based shark mitigation devices, which are currently being tested\"."]
